reviewText:
Summary:Two Digits is a logic game about finding two equal sums of numbers in sets with nine numbers (lower than 100). Don't expect anything else, you won't get it. :)

Positives:- Good idea for a logic game.

Neutrals:- Achievements are gained only for level solving (with exception of one), there aren't any especially hard ones.

Negatives:- 250 levels might sound great, though you might feel really bored after few tens of levels. It's just still the same without any innovation or perceptible gameplay change.
- Mouse control could be made more special for PC, not just quickly ported from smartphones and tablets. Why do we have to double-click if we can use left X right mouse button? Why can't we set controls?
voteText: 32 of 41 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Highly recommended.  A great game where you use your addition skills to add a combination or partial combination of a set of nine numbers so that you have two of the same number to solve the puzzle.  For example if the set included 22 and 17  and 33 and 6 you would have two 39's to solve the puzzle.  It sounds a bit more confusing than it actually is.  This would be a great game to play with your children or for adults who just enjoy a bit of mathematical challenge.  The soundtrack is very soothing as well.  Frankly steam needs more games like this that can be used as learning tools I can't get enough of them!
voteText: 15 of 18 people (83%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: So there are 9 numbers, out of those 9 you have to figure out what 3 of them will have the same sum as another 3 of them.  3 are not used in the solution.  If you like math puzzles like this combined with the sort of relaxing music you would expect in a game like this you will like this game.  The number of puzzles you get for the price is a good value.   2 suggestions - I'd like it if you could right click for one color and left click for the other color (as of now you need to click past the first color to get to the 2nd color) and multiple profiles or save slots.

reviewText: Make two piles of numbers which have the same sum"\nFirstly it's not a bad game concept at all. Two Digits is a solid but simple math puzzler. And a sequel named "Three Digits" is already out there
date: too. I just complain about the implementation.\n\n250 levels which turn into boring after a while. Why is that so? I guess it's the lack of slowly raising difficulty. The levels seem totally mixedup in difficulty and solution category. Tho it's always the 3x3 matrix some puzzles intermediate have solutions like x = a + b (+ c). Even the last 3 levels are ridiculous easy. The dev should figure out what makes a puzzle easy or what makes it more challenging. And then bring them in a new order. It mustn't be that mass of levels. The experience would be much better I think."

commentsCount:
except that far too many of these puzzles has one number in the set which is the sum of 2 other numbers. It's slightly hard to find this sometimes, but too many levels can be solved immediately like this.

If that fails, finding any two pairs of numbers with the same difference (5, 7, 33, 35, for example) also solves a puzzle.

And then there's puzzles where two of the numbers are the same. At least 3 of them, if I remember right. One duplicate, other duplicate in different groups is a solution.

There's really no difficulty ramp-up at all in this game, as a result. I found the all numbers are odd" part of the game far and away most enjoyable

reviewText:
I'm personally baffled by the positive reviews for this game. I guess there are just a lot of simple people out there.

When you brainstorm ideas for making a game, some you keep and some you throw out because they don't go anywhere. This game idea should've been thrown out.

Here's the idea behind this game: You have nine numbers. Pick two groups of those numbers that add up to the same amount. That's it. The gameplay does not get any deeper. Level 1 is literally the same as level 100, just with different numbers. With good game ideas, you find the gameplay expanding as the game goes on. This is just rote repetition. I can't imagine anyone enjoying it. If you do, you have an exciting career ahead of you as a cashier.

Some reviews say this game is educational, which I also don't understand. I'm not sure what these people could be learning. Did they not know how to tell if two numbers are equal before playing this? That could be it.

Bottom line, if you are 8 and need to practice your addition, or if you want to get into accounting for the thrills, buy this game. Otherwise, steer clear.

reviewText: Fun, relaxing puzzle game.  Most of the 250 puzzles were easy, though.  My strategy was find the difference between two of the numbers, call them a and b.  Then see if two other numbers, c and d, had the same difference.  Then the solution would be a+c and b+d.  Wasn't expecting that to work so often.  Either way, great game.\n\nNOTE:  On 5/30/2015, the developers released a major update which remastered the majority of the levels and fixed the achievements.  So the easiness" statement may no longer be relevant."

reviewText: Very simple concept. I love puzzle games and I loved this. There are 250 levels I'm about 1/5 in after 5 hours. I'm sure some genius can complete this really fast but this is good for casuals.  There are 9 numbers on the screen and you try to get 2 matches using some of the numbers.  For example, you have 1-9 and you can match 1 + 2 for one side and 3 for other side and you complete the level.  Of course the numbers are a mix of 2 digits or 1 digit numbers and is much harder.

reviewText:
Compared to the sequel Three Digits, Two Digits is actually an OK game. Of course there're some design problems, but still, it's fairly enjoyable calculation game and quite easy to get through all 250 level.

Some problems:

- The left and right portions of the screen are just empty. Making good use of the space will make the fonts bigger which will cause less eye usage problems.
- There are 3 prime number levels but one of them is not even composed by prime numbers.

reviewText:
I have not been playing for very long, but I really enjoy this game. The music is wonderful. The interface is clean. Nothing on the screen except the 9 digits and the background (ie no clutter). I'm not too sure if I can sit to play this game for hours on end, but it most certainly is a game that will fill waitings. Have 5-10 minutes to spare? Load this up. The game is such a simple concept. Add numbers together to ensure the left side equals the right side. Fear not if you are not wonderfully gifted in arithmetic, you can play this game using pattern recognition as well (assuming you can add numbers together less than 10). As of wrtiting this, there appear to be 250 levels to play in various categories (such as using numbers 1-30, using numbers 1-50, using 1-99, prime numbers, multiples of 3, etc). There is also a random mode in which you specify the lower bound and upper bound.

music - 9/10
visuals - 8/10
gameplay - 8/10
controls - 9/10
story - n/a

Overall I give this a 8.5/10. I will most likely be playing it in short increments for a while to come.

reviewText:
From what I've played so far, it's a very simplistic game, but that's not specifically why I wouldn't recommend it.

1. There are a LOT of levels. Normally, I'm not one to complain about too much content, but the additional levels do not add anything of value on top of normal game play. 250 levels is too many to justify individual selection and 'progress'. Levels should indicate a distinct progression: new mechanisms, bigger puzzles, etc. Levels here mean nothing in terms of playstyle. An example of what good level progression would be HexCells, where new worlds either introduce a new mechanic, or increase the difficulty of the puzzles. In Two Digits, the progression means nothing.

2. Poor PC porting. To anybody who has played this game or watched the trailers or screen shots, it's obvious this game was developed with touch screen in mind. If a game that is made on a different platform is ported to a new platform, the controls (or at least the options for controls) should reflect the new platform. In this case, it was minimally done. I see potential for left/right clicking to switch between states, but it was never addressed.

In my opinion, calling this a puzzle is a bit of a stretch. At the very least, it has puzzle elements, but this plays more like a math education game than your standard puzzle. For an educational game, it wouldn't be that bad (I could see a style of this game being extended to other operations and potentially being a great tool for educators), but as a puzzle game on Steam, it might be hitting the wrong core demographic. The concept's not bad, but I think the execution could be better.

reviewText: Do you love math? I don't mean in an abstract yes-this-concept-appeals-to-me sense, I mean do you love adding and subtracting ♥♥♥♥? If you can honestly answer yes, then Two Digits might very well be a game for you. The premise is as simple as you can get: You get nine numbers, and you have to pick two sets of numbers that equal each other when added. That might mean finding two numbers that add up to a third, or that might mean summing dozens of combinations until you hit upon one that works. It's a great game for taxing your brain, because you need to work out systems to identify potential equals. Looking for numbers one digit apart or ones that sum to others will save you a lot of headaches, so if you're good at coming up with math shortcuts, you'll be well prepared for this.\n\nThat's it. Literally it. You have several hundred puzzles of what I just described. There are no additional systems, gimmicks, unlocks, or features. The art style is clean and clear, and there's some pleasant background music to facilitate your puzzling. That is very, very much it. Two Digits lacks the sort of depth that something like Sudoku or Picross offers, but if you want straight math brain-teasers, that's exactly what you'll get. Honestly I can only really recommend the game to people that really really want that, so for unapologetic mathophiles it's a solid puzzler.

reviewText:
Not a horrendous game, but just a plain lazy port. 3/10

First of all, this game is $0.99 on the Google App store - and 4x as much on Steam. Chalk up another lazy programmer jacking up the Steam price even though it was the afterthought platform.

Secondly, this thing is an unoptimized mess. So you need to pick a number to be in bucket 1 or bucket 2 to make them match. Logically, right click = bucket 1, left click = bucket 2? Nope. This is a tablet game so you press a number twice to get it to bucket 2. So ok, I play this on my windows tablet and it glitches out where you can't scroll down on the level screen after using it for a bit, forcing a restart every once in awhile. For the Steam achievements, they don't unlock until you restart the game.

Bottom line is that the game is ok, but as a PC gamer you just can't support lazy, overpriced ports like this or it will be all we get. If you like puzzle games, I suggest some alternative choices (some of which are also ports - but aren't lazy messes like this game), like Hexcells, Strata, Cubot, Unium, etc.

reviewText:
I was very interested to this game when I saw this at greenlight. The concept is really nice, and I like the music in the video. I was looking forward to get this game. But after I play it, it disappoints me.

I was thinking the soundtrack DLC is the same as the video in store page, but it is not. And the background music dlc is too slow calm, makes me sleepy. For puzzle game like this, we need cheerful BGM. I prefer the music in store page video though.
Level selection screen does not support mouse scrolling. You have to drag the scrollbar to scroll the page. Very inefficient.
Steam achievement is not unlocked when you fulfill the requirement. Needs to restart the game to unlock the achievements. There is already a discussion about this. I'll edit my review if it is fixed.
Use multiple left-click to change the color of the number. For mobile it is good, but is not efficient for pc game where we can do left-click and right-click.
The value of red is placed at the right bottom screen. Steam notification overlay will cover up the number, so it is pretty annoying to wait for the notification to disappear. The UI is not crowded either, so it'll be better if the number values placed at upper corner.
Too bad, I tried to like this game, but as it is now, I don't recommend it.

reviewText: This is a clear case of what you see is what you get.  Nine numbers appear, none greater than 99, and you assign some to green and some to orange until the green and orange sums are equal.  You don't have to use every number.  I did the 250 available levels, but there is never really a significant change in difficulty.  Maybe more levels will be added later, but they don't really have a hand-crafted feel to them anyway, and you might just as well play the random generator.  You can assign numbers randomly and occasionally happen upon a solution, but some in-your-head math strategy can move you along faster.  When you get a solution, the numbers disappear, so I hardly ever noticed if there were multiple possible solutions.  At least a few times, there certainly are.  Anyway, if you like counting puzzles, go for it.

reviewText:
Enjoyable little game.

Three small ways that I would quickly improve it:
1. Enable scroll on the main menu
2. Make green colour left click and red right click, instead of having to cycle.
3. After pressing reset, don't make the numbers disappear.
I think that details like this are important in minimalistic games.

7/10

Edit: Achievements don't unlock when they should (often only when you next launch the game) and steam pop-up boxes appear but don't disappear (glitching on the screen) when playing the game.
